title: My ex asked me to take her to inpatient care and I mistakenly called her parents in the process. I would really like some female perspectives on this.
opening_message: I'm still having trouble processing the intense situation that unfolded when my ex's parents showed up unannounced and became aggressive towards me.

all: My ex had been through a traumatic experience - she was raped by her abusive ex after we got together.
She kept most things to herself, so I had to work hard to get her to open up about her feelings and experiences.
When she reached out for help, I tried to be supportive and make arrangements for the kids' care, but her parents were uncooperative and hostile towards me.
Her father attacked me at the door when he came over unannounced, and things escalated quickly due to his anger and disregard for my ex's feelings.
Her family didn't want her to receive mental healthcare or inpatient care, and they blamed me for trying to help her get the support she needed.
I felt overwhelmed and suffered from trauma myself, which led me to call the cops when things got out of hand.
After the incident, my ex distanced herself from me and told me that I shouldn't have tried to keep her family away, implying that I was causing her more harm than good.
Her parents took control of everything in her life - apartment, car, job, and savings - which felt like a betrayal of our relationship and her autonomy.
Two months later, I'm still struggling to process the aftermath and trying to make sense of what happened.
I feel lost and uncertain about how to move forward, and I'm seeking advice from others to help me work through my emotions and make amends if possible.

turns.content: I'm still having trouble processing the intense situation that unfolded when my ex's parents showed up unannounced and became aggressive towards me.

That sounds incredibly stressful and overwhelming! It's no wonder you're struggling to process it all. Can you tell me more about what was going through your mind during that interaction? How did you feel like you were treated by them?

I felt totally disrespected and belittled by him. Like, I was just trying to have a calm conversation with my partner about what was going on, and then he shows up out of nowhere and starts yelling at me like I'm some kind of child who can't even think for myself. It was so frustrating and made me feel really small and powerless.

Ugh, that sounds absolutely infuriating! It's clear you were already feeling anxious about the situation, and then his parents' behavior just escalated it to a whole new level. How did your partner react during all of this? Did they try to intervene or support you at all?

I felt so frustrated and powerless during that whole ordeal. My partner tried to be supportive, but honestly, I think they were caught off guard by how intense my family's reaction was. They didn't really know what to do, so they just kind of stood back and let things escalate. It was like, even their attempts to help me felt like they were taking sides or something.

It can be really tough when we feel like our partner isn't fully on our side during a stressful situation. That must have made you feel even more isolated and alone. Can you tell me what you needed from your partner at that moment? What would've helped you feel more supported and less frustrated?

"I think what I needed from her at that moment was for her to acknowledge that I was trying to protect myself and our relationship. Instead of distancing herself and making me feel like I was the problem, it would've been huge if she could've met me halfway and understood where I was coming from. It felt like she was more worried about pleasing her family than supporting me through a tough time."

That makes so much sense! It sounds like you were craving some understanding and validation from your partner during that intense moment. And instead, you felt like she wasn't fully on your side, which can be really hurtful. How are things between you two now? Has there been any conversation or healing since then?

Honestly, things are still pretty rocky between us. We haven't had a deep conversation about it yet, just some surface-level apologies and promises to "work through this". But for me, it's hard to shake off the feeling that she didn't really get what I was going through, you know? It's like, even though we've both said sorry, I still feel like there's this unspoken disconnect between us.

It can be really tough to move past a experience like that without some meaningful conversation and healing. It sounds like you're still feeling the emotional aftermath of that situation. What do you think would need to happen for you to start feeling like your partner truly understands what you went through?

I feel so frustrated and hurt that my partner's family didn't even try to understand or support us during that difficult time. It feels like they just dismissed our concerns and made things harder for us, and it still really stings. I think what would help me feel like my partner truly gets it is if she acknowledges how her family's behavior affected me and apologizes for not standing up for us more.

It sounds like you're craving some acknowledgment and accountability from your partner about the hurt that was caused by her family's actions. That's a really important step in healing and rebuilding trust. Do you feel like you've had any hints or suggestions that she might be willing to have this kind of conversation with you?

Honestly, I've been sensing some mixed signals from her lately. On one hand, she's made efforts to apologize and understand my perspective, but on the other hand, it feels like she's still not fully acknowledging the severity of what happened or taking responsibility for how her family's actions affected me. It's like we're stuck in this gray area where I'm left feeling unheard and dismissed.

It sounds like you're sensing that there might be some unresolved issues between you two, and it's causing you to feel uncertain about the future of your relationship. What do you think would happen if you were to have a more direct conversation with her about how you're feeling - would you want to try to work through this together or is it time to re-evaluate things?

I think if we had a direct conversation about this, she would probably get defensive because it's a sensitive topic for her. And honestly, I'm not sure I want to go down that road again - it feels like walking on eggshells around her parents' influence in our relationship. It's hard for me to feel like we're equals when they're still so deeply involved in every aspect of her life.

It can be really draining and stressful to navigate complex family dynamics, especially when you feel like it's affecting your relationship. It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by the idea of dealing with another potentially difficult conversation. How do you think you would need to prioritize self-care and boundaries in order to take care of yourself during this time?

"I feel like I'm constantly walking on eggshells around my family members, never knowing what's really going on beneath the surface. It's like I'm always trying to read between the lines, but it's exhausting because I'm not sure if I'll ever get the whole truth. And now, with this upcoming conversation, I feel like I need to be prepared for anything and yet, at the same time, I'm terrified of getting hurt or disappointed again."
